text: Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. text: Patient: Not at all. Not at all. Doctor: Thanks for fixing your hepatitis. I’m real, thank you, I’m glad that it’s done. Patient: Got that did. Doctor: Dr. J____ treated you right. Patient: I’ve got a - I’ve got my uh colonoscopy. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I got that did. Doctor: Yep. See slowly we’re fixing you up. Patient: Yeah I’ll be good in no time. Okay. (laughs) Doctor: The only thing not behaving is your prostate number though. Patient: That’s because I didn’t get it. After three months it was four and a half. That’s what happened. Doctor: Yeah. You still shouldn’t be sort of rising.

text: Family Member: Oh, they’re taping us now? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh, I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. We’re getting his whole lunch live right now in color Doctor: Well I’m glad you’re feeling a little better. Just you know take your time. We’re okay. We’ll see what that PSA shows. I’m glad we straightened out the whole pill action and everything else. Patient: Yeah. That’s all been handled. Doctor: But you know with the XTANDI it makes you tired. Then sometimes you don’t really want to eat. And it’s hard, you’re such a tough diabetic to begin with, minus the pills. You being on it like you are is probably the best thing for you to stay on it because you might bottom out a lot faster than normal. Okay? Patient: Okay. Family Member: And he has been going low a little bit now and then. Doctor: Yeah. Well because you’re so used to being very high. Patient: Well, you know, I-no I’m not used to being very high. Doctor: Well, yeah, except when you come here you’re high.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign. Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. text: Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. text: Patient: Oh, mind blowing. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yes. Doctor: You did like safaris and stuff? I remember you told me about it. Patient: Yeah. We did safaris and the scenery. Family Member: Yeah. We did. It was nice. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: All right. Good. That’s good. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not. Doctor: You’re right. Chemically, we do it to say this is what's happening Patient: Right. Doctor: - to your testosterone but everyone reacts to the different preparations differently. Patient: The Lupron just knocked me for a loop. They wanted me to be on Lupron for three years, and after a year, I told him I'd rather die. Doctor: Yeah, because it was terrible. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study!
